Context / details: Write simply, directly, and correctly. Do not explain things that go without saying. Avoid repetition.
Friendly but not chatty. Find the middle ground between "corporate/cold" and "fluff".
Use short, plain, common words. Do not invent words or use slang.
Individual elements (headings, buttons) must stand on their own without surrounding context.
Follow American English rules (Merriam-Webster dictionary). Use American spelling (e.g., "Color" not "Colour").
Use "fill out a form" instead of "fill in".
Use the plural form for items that can be singular or plural. Do not use brackets like Asset(s).
Use present tense to describe product behavior. Avoid future tense for how the product always acts.
Capitalize only the first word of sentences, headings, buttons, and labels (except proper nouns).
Preserve capitalization of proper names and abbreviations (e.g., "API key", "Content Hub ONE").
Do not hard-code uppercase text. Use CSS (text-transform: uppercase) if stylistic uppercase is needed.
Do not use periods on solo sentences (headers, buttons, toasts, inputs, tooltips).
End all sentences in body text (persistent text in page/dialog body) with a period.
Use a period after a solo sentence if it is followed by a link.
Avoid exclamation points. Use only one if necessary for sincere congratulations.
Use numerals instead of words (e.g., "3 messages"). Exception: Use words when mixing numbers (e.g., "Enter two 3s").
Leave a space between value and unit (e.g., "123 MB"). Exception: No space for single-character units (e.g., "1080p", "5d").
Ensure truncated text ends with an ellipsis and provide the full text in a tooltip.
Describe the specific action (concise, 1-2 words). Do not use ending punctuation.
Use "Create {thing}" (e.g., "Create widget"). Avoid "New {thing}" or "Create new {thing}".
Use Create if the opposite is Destroy/Delete (high stakes). Use Add if the opposite is Remove (low stakes).
For Content Hub, creation buttons use the format + {ThingName} to avoid translation issues.
The dialog title must match the button clicked to open it (e.g., Button "Edit widget" -> Title "Edit widget").
Use explicit verbs for buttons (e.g., "Enable", "Delete"). Avoid ambiguous text like "Yes", "No", or "OK".
Use exactly two options: 1. "Keep editing" (return to form), 2. "Discard" (lose changes).
Use "Dismiss" or "OK" to acknowledge. Avoid "Cancel" on purely informative dialogs.
"Close" closes the dialog. "Cancel" cancels the actions/settings within the dialog.

Avoid "Title / Description" structure; it creates redundancy.
Use a word or phrase (not a sentence). Do not use punctuation (no colons).
Use helper text generously to provide context or instructions.
Avoid placeholder text inside input fields. Exception: Search or filter boxes.
Explain the error and how to fix it immediately.
Use active, positive wording (e.g., "Send me a copy"). Avoid negations ("Don't send") or questions.
Do not add a period at the end of a checkbox label.
Group labels should explain the purpose. Option labels should focus on the differences between choices.
Use US order: Month Day, Year (e.g., Dec 6, 2020).
Write out the month, abbreviated to 3 letters (e.g., "Dec").
Do not use leading zeros (use "6" not "06"). Do not use ordinals (use "Dec 6" not "Dec 6th").
Use 12-hour clock with AM/PM (e.g., 2:23 PM).
